Use of CHOIR for patient outcome measures in Pediatric Orthopaedic Surgery Clinics

FOR QUESTIONS ABOUT THE STUDY, CONTACT: Steven Frick, MD and/or Katherine Hastings, MPH. 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford, CA 94305. 650-721-7669, 650-498-2588.

DESCRIPTION: You are invited to participate in a research study on collecting information electronically using the Collaborative Health Outcomes Information Registry (CHOIR) database. You will be asked questions about clinical outcome measures (for example, how well you can move, if you have any pain) on a paper form and/or on an electronic form on a tablet. We plan to use this data for tracking clinical outcomes measures over time, for quality improvement, of as well as for recruitment for future studies.

RISKS AND BENEFITS: There are no risks associated with this study. The benefits which may reasonably be expected to result from this study are the development of an efficient, effective, and organized way of viewing and managing information collected routinely through our clinical practice. We cannot and do not guarantee or promise that you will receive any benefits from this study.

Your decision whether or not to participate in this study will not affect your employment/medical care.

TIME INVOLVEMENT: Your participation in this experiment will take approximately 15 minutes, and an additional 5-10 minutes for any follow up surveys.

PAYMENTS: You will not receive payment for your participation.

PARTICIPANT'S RIGHTS: If you have read this form and have decided to participate in this project, please understand your participation is voluntary and you have the right to withdraw your consent or discontinue participation at any time without penalty or loss of benefits to which you are otherwise entitled.

The results of this research study may be presented at scientific or professional meetings or published in scientific journals. However, your identity will not be disclosed.

You have the right to refuse to answer particular questions.

Authorization To Use Your Health Information For Research Purposes

Because information about you and your health is personal and private, it generally cannot be used in this research study without your authorization. If you authorize, it will provide the authorization to use your health information. The form is intended to inform you about how your health information will be used or disclosed in the study. Your information will only be used in accordance with this authorization form and the informed consent form and as required or allowed by law. Please read it carefully before authorizing.

What is the purpose of this research study and how will my health information be utilized in the study?

The purpose of this protocol is to collect patient outcome data electronically using the Collaborative Health Outcomes Information Registry (CHOIR) database. You will be asked questions about clinical outcome measures (for example, how well you can move, if you have any pain) on a paper form and/or on an electronic form on a tablet. We plan to use this data for tracking clinical outcomes measures over time, for quality improvement, of as well as for recruitment for future studies.

Do I have to sign this authorization form?

You do not have to authorize. But if you do not, you will not be able to participate in this research study.

If I sign, can I revoke it or withdraw from the research later?

If you decide to participate, you are free to withdraw your authorization regarding the use and disclosure of your health information (and to discontinue any other participation in the study) at any time. After any revocation, your health information will no longer be used or disclosed in the study, except to the extent that the law allows us to continue using your information (e.g., necessary to maintain integrity of research). If you wish to revoke your authorization for the research use or disclosure of your health information in this study, you must write to: Steven Frick, MD and/or Katherine Hastings, MPH. 300 Pasteur Drive, Stanford, CA 94305. 650-721-7669, 650-725-5339.

What Personal Information Will Be Obtained, Used or Disclosed?

Your health information related to this study, may be used or disclosed in connection with this research study, including, but not limited to your name, medical record number, zip code, birth date, telephone number, electronic mail address, and medical chart information. This information will be kept confidential and secured with limited access to authorized member of to study team at Stanford.

Who May Use or Disclose the Information?

The following parties are authorized to use and/or disclose your health information in connection with this research study:

  • The Protocol Director Steven Frick, MD
  • The Stanford University Administrative Panel on Human Subjects in Medical Research and any other unit of Stanford University as necessary
  • Research Staff including the Stanford School of Medicine Research IT team

Who May Receive or Use the Information?

The parties listed in the preceding paragraph may disclose your health information to the following persons and organizations for their use in connection with this research study:

  • The Office for Human Research Protections in the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
Your information may be re-disclosed by the recipients described above, if they are not required by law to protect the privacy of the information.

When will my authorization expire?

Your authorization for the use and/or disclosure of your health information will end on December 31, 2050 or when the research project ends, whichever is earlier.

WITHDRAWAL FROM STUDY

The Protocol Director may also withdraw you from the study without your consent for one or more of the following reasons:

  • Failure to follow the instructions of the Protocol Director and study staff.
  • The Protocol Director decides that continuing your participation could be harmful to you.
  • The study is cancelled.
  • Other administrative reasons.
  • Unanticipated circumstances.

CONTACT INFORMATION:

Questions, Concerns, or Complaints: If you have any questions, concerns or complaints about this research study, its procedures, risks and benefits, or alternative courses of treatment, you should ask the Protocol Director, Steven Frick, MD. You may contact him/her now or later at 650-721-7669.

Independent Contact: If you are not satisfied with how this study is being conducted, or if you have any concerns, complaints, or general questions about the research or your rights as a participant, please contact the Stanford Institutional Review Board (IRB) to speak to someone independent of the research team at (650)-723-5244 or toll free at 1-866-680-2906. You can also write to the Stanford IRB, Stanford University, 3000 El Camino Real, Five Palo Alto Square, 4th Floor, Palo Alto, CA 94306.

Alternate Contact: If you cannot reach the Protocol Director, please contact Katherine Hastings, MPH at (650-725-5339)

Response.label: Assent Form
Response.CollapsibleContent:
Use of CHOIR for patient outcome measures in Pediatric Orthopaedic Surgery Clinics

1. What will happen to me in this study?

You are invited to participate in a research study on collecting information electronically using the Collaborative Health Outcomes Information Registry (CHOIR) database. You will be asked questions about how you are doing (for example, how well you can move? do you have any pain?) on a paper form and/or on an electronic form on a tablet. We plan to use this information to look at changes in these clinical outcomes measures over time, for quality improvement, of as well as for recruitment for future studies.

2. Can anything bad happen to me?

No, we expect nothing bad to happen to you if you complete our forms.

3. Can anything good happen to me?

The benefits that reasonably to expect from this study are the development of an efficient, effective, and organized way of viewing and managing clinical information collected routinely from patients like you.

4. Do I have other choices?

Your participation is voluntary. You have the right to withdraw or discontinue participation at any time.

5. Will anyone know I am in the study?

Your participation in the study will be kept secret.

6. What happens if I get hurt?

Your parents/legal guardians have been given information on what to do if you are injured during the study.

7. Who can I talk to about the study?

If you have any questions about the study or any problems to do with the study, you can contact the Protocol Director Steven Frick. You can call him/her at (650) 721-7669. You can also call the Research Manager, Katherine Hastings, MPH (650) 725-5339.

If you have questions about the study but want to talk to someone else who is not a part of the study, you can call the Stanford Institutional Review Board (IRB) at (650)-723-5244 or toll free at 1-866-680-2906.

8. What happens if I turn 18 while participating in the study?

If you turn the age of 18 after agreeing to participate in this study, you will be asked to re-consent as an adult during your next scheduled follow up survey (by email) or clinical visit (in person).

9. What if I do not want to do this

You can stop being in the study at any time without getting in trouble and your doctor will continue to treat you if treatment is necessary and available.
